title: Juul's CEO just stepped down and the e-cig company said it will stop all advertising in the US
text:
Juul announced in a statement on its website that Kevin Burns, CEO of the e-cigarette company has stepped down from the role.

Juul also said, effective immediately, that it would be "suspending all broadcast, print and digital product advertising in the US."

The US Food and Drug Administration has been cracking down on Juul for portraying its e-cigs as "totally safe" as it marketed them to children.

View Markets Insider's homepage for more stories

Juul on Wednesday said CEO Kevin Burns has stepped down and that Altria executive KC Crosthwaite will take over the role effective immediately.

The $38 billion company, which is part-owned by tobacco giant Altria, said it will also be "suspending all broadcast, print and digital product advertising in the US," and "refraining from lobbying the administration on its draft guidance and committing to fully support and comply with the final policy when effective."

The personnel change comes a day after the Wall Street Journal reported California federal prosecutors have launched a criminal probe into Juul. Juul is also under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the Food and Drug Administration, and several state attorneys general. Walmart said last week it will end sales of the e-cig products.

The FTC is looking into whether Juul used social-media influencers and forms of marketing to pitch its product to minors, while the FDA is considering several issues including the high nicotine content of Juul's refill pods.

The Trump administration also announced this month that it plans to ban most flavored e-cigarettes. "We can't allow people to get sick," Trump told reporters. "And we can't have our kids be so affected."

Earlier this month Business Insider reported that the US FDA criticized Juul for portraying its e-cigs as "totally safe" as it marketed them to children.

As "Chief Growth Officer" at Altria Group, Crosthwaite "oversaw the company's expansion into alternatives to combustible cigarettes and played a key role in the commercial and regulatory efforts related to the US launch of IQOS," Juul said. He was also an "observer" on Juul Labs' board of directors.

"In his new role, Crosthwaite and the entire Juul Labs leadership team will continue a broad review of the company's practices and policies to ensure alignment with its aim of responsible leadership within the industry," the company said in the statement on its website.

The FDA warned Juul in September 9 letter: "Referring to your ENDS products as '99% safer' than cigarettes, 'much safer' than cigarettes, 'totally safe,' and 'a safer alternative than smoking cigarettes' is particularly concerning because these statements were made directly to children in school."

Burns, in an interview with CBS in August, warned against the use of using Juul's products. Burns at the time said that anyone who was not already using nicotine should not use Juul products due to the addictive nature of the drug.

"Don't vape. Don't use Juul," Burns told Tony Dokoupil, adding "Don't start using nicotine if you don't have a preexisting relationship with nicotine."
